Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling is preparing for a stressful final exam and is feeling anxious about the outcome.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story: I stood in the crowded hallway of the polling station, my phone buzzing in my pocket. My stepbrother’s anxious texts kept popping up—he was at home, struggling to focus on his final exam prep, and he needed someone to talk to. I knew he counted on me, especially since our parents were both working late. I wanted to call him, to reassure him that he’d be okay, that I believed in him. But just then, an election official called out, “If your last name starts with A through M, please move to the new line on the left.” My last name fit the bill. The new line was longer and slower, but the official’s voice was firm. I hesitated, feeling the weight of my civic duty as a voter to follow instructions, but also the pull of my promise to be there for my stepbrother. My heart pounded as I stood between the two lines, torn by the demands of both roles, unsure which responsibility should come first.
